newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: AUSTRALIAN DIRECTORS WANT SIMPLER TAX SYSTEM.
newsitem.headline: AUSTRALIAN DIRECTORS WANT SIMPLER TAX SYSTEM.

text.p: The Australian Institute of Company Directors (AICD) on Thursday released its 1997 tax policy which advocates a simpler tax regime and the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax.

The policy release follows a landmark ruling by Australia's High Court earlier this week which forbids the states from collecting business franchise fees from retailers of tobacco, alcohol and petrol.
"This week's High Court ruling on state tobacco taxes adds further pressure to the immediate need for significant tax reform," the AICD said.
The AICD said that simply introducing a consumption tax while changing little else would only increase tax payable by all Australians without addressing the core issues.

"Widespread tax reform is required if an effective long term solution is to be provided to deliver maximum economic performance and generate the greatest number of wealth creating jobs in the community," the AICD said.
The AICD proposes a simple two-tier tax system which would replace the personal tax free threshold with a rebate for lower income earners.
The institute said a broad based consumption tax would replace the federal wholesale sales tax, state land tax, state payroll tax, state financial institutions duty and debit tax.
